body:
The above scenario is equivalent to deleting all files from r1.
Consider that you delete whole files in some repository, what behavior do you expect ?

then I come back to my last question:
How could I change the directory of a repo on a machine and do an "initial sync" without having to take care of deleting all files on other repos? Do I have to delete the repo on the machine and create a new one (with the same ID)?
Can't you just copy the files (or hardlink) and then point the repo to the new directory, and delete the old one?

@marcindziadus i see your point, but i'd expect, that syncthing can distinguish between an event like "all the files in a folder that i scan have disapeared" and "someone changed my config, i shall use another folder for the same documents from now an".
Maybe this case could be handled instead of manually copying / moving  things around. Because if i dont have enough space for copying the files, i'd have to do:
- [ ] shutdown syncting (to prevent the deletion on move) 
- [ ] move the files to the new folder
- [ ] manually change the path in the config file (to prevent automatic deletion by syncthing)
- [ ] finally (re)start syncthing

not the best solution IMHO
There is a lot of logic to prevent accidental deletions already. It sounds like this would be a case where things could be accidentally deleted. At least a warning should be given.

So I think it could be a bug depending on the intentions of the developer.

The way I _think_ syncthing works is by keeping a lamport clock each repo (or perhaps even file), a lamport clock is just a version, which after each detected file/directory/structure change gets incremented by one. As nodes communicate they always accept higher versions of the index than the one they have, and this way work out what to sync (comparing to what is on the disk).

Now when you change the path of the repo, that doesn't reset the counter for the repo, and therefore when the next scan happens, it says, "oh okay, something has changed as the indexes don't match, lets increment the counter and advertise my new index to everyone", and then all nodes receive the empty index with higher version, deleting everything, which you could say is a bug.

But then there is the reverse option of this:

I have directory A with files `a`, `b`, `c` synced between nodes, now since I use some other method of transfer, I have a newer version of directory A (called B) with files `a`, `b`, `c`, `d` located somewhere else on my disk, I decided that I should instead point the syncthing repo from dir A to dir B... For it to be synced with all the nodes as that has the new file I've added....
Now if we were to fix the above bug by resetting the version on repo path change, this would cause file `d` to be deleted locally.

Therefore when changing repo path, the answer is to ask,`is this a newer version of the existing repo`, or `do you want to move the repo there`.

Currently syncthing has no notion of what the path to a repository has been historically. We know the files we have (or used to have) in the repo as tuples of {repository ID, path within repo}. So yeah, when you change the repo path, what syncthing sees is that there are suddenly no files.

Note that you must actually create an empty repository path and change the config to point to it for this to happen. If you change the repo path to point to something that doesn't exist, syncthing will warn and complain.

As always, there are corner cases. What if you change the path to something that is not empty? That contains files that are different from the currently "in sync" versions? Containing files that have previously been deleted? etc
In the meantime, the repo path should probably not be editable in the GUI. Yes, that's annoying, but it illustrates the limitation and removes the footgun.

There's probably a related bug as well, as I don't think the index is cleared out when a repo is removed. So removing a repo, then adding it again with a different path (but same ID) will result in the same behavior as above.
I can confirm that, calmh. Just did this and wondered why all files were gone.

Just to add possible problem, what would happen, if booting system fails to mount filesystem where repo is located and syncthing will start as usual?

I can foresee some catastrophic results here.

Not really, as you'd still have the files inside the device which failed to mount.
As you'd mount the filesystem, the index would get updated, and all other nodes would start pulling files from the node with the failed mount.

issue.title: Shared folders are read-only on sd card  (<29) and inaccessible on all ext. storage (>=29, ~November 2020)

labels.name: android-restriction
labels.description: Caused by a recently introduced android restriction

issue.body:
SyncThing works great for repositories created on the internal SDCard. However if I try to create a rep on my external SDCard it doesn't complain. The other node attempts to sync & just shows sync progress set at 0%.
I'm running Android 4.4.2 on a GS4 & I know external SD card access for apps got restricted more since 4.4 but I think SyncThing is one of those apps where it makes complete sense to have ext SD access.
In the short term perhaps SyncThing for Android could complain if ext SD card access is not an option?

issue.title: Can't change default folder parameters.

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body:
The default folder parameters are not configurable. Any reason why? I wanted to move the directory from `~/Sync` to something else.

Cheers
